title: Kelly eyeing up more sporting qualifications
story: ANNACLOY teenager Hannah Kelly recently qualied in the IFArsquos Grassroots Introductory Award.The  year-old St Colmcillersquos High School pupil has a keen interest in sport and aims to achieve more qualications as she seeks her pathway in le.The Year  student is a dedicated Liverpool fan and is certainly ahead of the game as she is keen to seek out other sporting opportunities.She is part of the Teconnaught girlsrsquo GAA team and also plays for both her schoolrsquos soccer and Gaelic football teams.The Crossgar school is currently one of the top sporting institutions in the district as it promotes, coaches and attends all local sporting events with their students.The driving force behind the schoolrsquos sporting achievements is enthusiastic PE teacher, Susan McMullan, who understands the importance of sporting activities.ldquoNot only is it my job, but I believe it is vital that my students avail of all the sporting opportunities that we can accept as the outcomes of sport are endless, she said.ldquoI want our students leaving our school having experienced a wide iety of sporting experiences through practical participation and qualications as the benefits of health, mental, social and friendships is so evident.The quietly confident Hannah certainly doesnrsquot wait for opportunities to fall on her lap as she sources out where she wants to go.ldquoI suppose, coming from a family where sport is played and spoken about most days, it is only natural that I may go down that routeI decide too, she enthused.ldquoThe next stage of my own personal development will be attending my work experience next March with local soccer coach Seamus Heath and I am already looking forward to shadowing him and learning how football development works.Seamus said: ldquoI feel strongly that it is our duty to help, advise and assist our young people,we can, as sporting participation can be a le-long experiencewe treat it properly and provide proper opportunities.For further information contact Seamus at sheath@irishfa or call  ..prettyPhoto

title: Oisin boxes clever to win novice title
story: OISIN Morgan, who boxes for Bryansford ABC, recently reached the semi-finals of Ulster  County Novice tournament and also won the Louth Novice Open final.In the Ulster  County Novice, Oisin won his quarter final with style, in a classy, hit-move boxing performance.Oisinrsquos opponent kept the pressure on right until the end, but was no match for his speed and skill as the Bryansford teenager cruised to victory on a unanimous decision.Unfortunately, the semi-final was a dferent story. Despite a gutsy performance, he was unable to deal with his opponentrsquos height and range advantage.He accepted the loss with grace and ed to the drawing board in preparation for Louth.The Louth Open Novice final saw Oisin battle it out with an equally hungry competitor.The two were well matched in size and style. Oisin kept his opponent on the back foot as he stalked him for the entire three rounds.Both fighters engaged in heated exchanges, but Oisin was able to maintain his composure, controlling the range and landing more frequent eye-catching shots.Credit to Oisinrsquos opponent, who continually forced him back and on occasions successfully broke through his defence.This was met with a quick response from Oisin, re-establishing his control. The result from the judges was a split decision, giving Oisin the win.This is his last competition as a novice. We look forward to see him on a bigger stage next season..prettyPhoto

title: Ross roasts rivals with divine treble
story: A RAVENOUS Killough side rekindled their love affair with the NFU Bobby Dalzell Cup at Binnian Park on Friday night when they blitzed Ballynagross with an irresistible display.Ballynahinch Olympic Town are now standing in Killoughrsquos way of bringing Bobby home and their fate will be decided in the Boxing Day showdown at Meadowvale.The Mountain Quarter side were left battered, bruised and bewildered as the voracious Killough mob raced into an unassailable - interval lead.A mixture of Ballynagross tightening things up all over the park in the second half and Killoughrsquos waning interest, ensured that there was only one goal scored after the break with Conor Marron netting a consolation from the penalty spot.Killough showed their intent from early on as they closed Ballynagross down like a pack of bounty hunters chasing their prey.Tony McIlhone, Adam George, Matt McKiernan and Gareth George bossed the middle of the park with a high press.They refused to give Ballynagross time on the ball and with all four operating from a central position and then spreading out to close the player of the ball down, there was no time for Philip Campbellrsquos beleaguered troops to settle.With just two minutes gone Killough struck. McIlhone won the ball off a Ballynagross defender and without even looking up let one fly from  yards out.Goalkeeper Ross Preece was stranded in no manrsquos land and his despairing outstretched attempt to tip the ball over the crossbar failed as the ball nestled in the back of the net.Two minutes later, man of the match Ross Armstrong made it -. He chased a lost cause of a ball into the box where Marron and Preece were favourites to win the race, but Armstrongrsquos sheer desire helped to get him to the ball first and he was able to dink it into an empty net.With  minutes gone Armstrong pounced again to make it - after McIlhone had carved out the opening.Killough continued to bombard Ballynagross with everything and anything, but Ballynagross bravely weathered the storm and gradually started to create chances of their own.With  minutes gone they patiently worked an opening for Ryan McKinney, but he was denied a goal when the impressive Sean Og Burns got back to hack the ball off the line.That was as good as it got for Ballynagross as Killough made it - three minutes later. Gareth George picked the ball up from a Ben McLaughlin throw and immediately set off on one of his trademark, penetrating runs.George had only one thing on his mind after leaving three players for dead and his unerring finish into the bottom corner had Preece clutching at thin air.Six minutes later it was - when Armstrong headed a free back across the box and McIlhone had all the time in the world to send Killough into delirium.With  minutes gone a delightful cross from Adam George was met perfectly by Armstrong and the big striker powered an unstoppable header to the net to make it -.Some of Killoughrsquos play in the first half was breathtaking and few teams could have lived with them and as the players trooped off at half-time, everyone feared for Ballynagross.However, the break gave Campbell the chance to reorganise his troops and the were a dferent proposition in the second half.Marron pulled one back from the spot after Sean Og Burns took down Philip Doran in the box, but despite creating several other chances, that was it for Ballynagross.Eoin Rooney and Conor McCarron had shots well saved by Killough lsquokeeper Eddie Hinc, while Liam Graham headed over at the other end and Preece saved from Gareth George.Killough were a pale shadow of the side that lit up Binnian Park in the first  minutes, but they can be forgiven for taking their foot off the pedal after taking a - lead.Ballynagross can only reflect on what might have been, had they been able to field at full strength, but football can be a cruel game as they found out on Friday night.Killough: Eddie Hinc, Matthew Burns, Ben McLaughlin, Colm Stranney, Sean Og Burns, Matt McKiernan, Gareth George, Adam George, Tony McIlhone, Ross Armstrong, Riain Burns: Subs: Liam Graham, Seamas Tumelty, Ryan McIlhone, Robbie Hagan, Ruairi Sharvin.Ballynagross: Ross Preece, Deaglan Craig, Tom McNeill, Aaron Beattie, Conor Marron, Conor McCarron, Karl Johnston, Mark Magill, Daniel Taggart, Declan Dowie, Ryan McKinney. Subs: John Shields, Philip Doran, Eoin Rooney, Gareth Robinson, Cormac Byrne.Killough Ballynagross BOBBY DALZELL CUP SEMI-FINAL.prettyPhoto

title: Seaforde keep up rich vein of form
story: AT the halfway point of the season itrsquos tight at the top as only a half point separate the reigning champions Seaforde from their old foes from St Maryrsquos, Killyleagh mdash itrsquos going to be an interesting second half to see who comes out on top.A great battle is developing for third spot between Marina and Loughinisland with the latter holding a . point lead. The Islanders have really surprised everyone this year as they make a greatto the top ision.Down at the other end of the table its looking like Drumaroad will be heading to relegation unless their fortunes change dramatically, the other place will be fought between Kilmegan and Bright with just a point and a half between them.St Michaelrsquos, Dundrum and St Patrickrsquos Golf Club should be safe in mid-table, but the Golfers have really taken a turn for the worse and are struggling to pick up points, so might find themselves in a relegation fight.DRUMAROAD.SEAFORDE YFC.SEAFORDE made the short trip to the lsquoFin to play a home side still looking for their first win of the season and came away with a good haul of points to keep their lead at the top of the table.A half decent start for the home side as the rinks of Joe Scullion and David Boal finished in a - draw. On the other mat Graham Christiersquos rink of Robert Shaw, Trevor Perry and Kirsty Burns had a good - win over Thomas Walsh for the visitors.The next two games were tight affairs as Hugh Burns held on a - win against Kevin Walsh while the home four of Liam Dummigan, Maire Scullion, Adrian Mussen and Harry Addis scored a single on the last end against Peter Christie for a - win.After tea the visitors took control of the match with a clean sweep of wins with Graham Christie doubling up with a - win over the Addis four and David Boal leading his rink of Alan Bleue, Joy Perry and Paddy Burns to a - win against Kevin Walsh.The rinks of Peter Christie and Hugh Burns wrapped the match up for Seaforde with wins of - and -.KILMEGAN.ST MARYrsquoS, KILLYLEAGH.THE Saints made the trip to Castlewellan knowing they needed a good result to stay with the league leaders Seaforde after their good win earlier in the week and they managed to match their rivals to keep it tight at the top.Ricky Cathcart and his rink of Liz Murray, Stevie Brown and Keiran McMullan got the challenge off to a great start by not losing an end for a - win over Micky Keown.On the other mat Paddy Murray was having a great tussle against Don Corrigan and his rink of Jean King, Rose McAllister and Hugh McCann, who scored seven shots on the third end, but just lost out - to the visitors.Another two big wins for the visitors on the next run as Neil Brown and Tony Ward also racked up double figure wins of - and - against Brendan Corrigan and Noreen Magorrian to go into the break with a  shot advantage. After tea the home Magorrian four secured a low scoring draw of - against the Murray rink and the away Cathcart secured another good win of - over Brendan Corrigan.The final run of games would end up being shared as the Brown four got another away point with a - win over the Keown rink, but credit to the rink skipped by Don Corrigan as they won the last end for a - win over the away Ward rink to secure a win and draw for this Kilmegan four.BRIGHT.ST PATRICKrsquoS GC.THE home side took full advantage of an understrength Golf Club side who arrived with only the minimum  players, so were always losing a quarter of their shots total.The match actually started well for the visitors as Laurence Craig, Ernie Kenmore and David Gibson ended up with a - win over Niall Polley.Hugh Porter and his rink of Raymond Kearney, Linda Cherry and Sean Deegan hit back with a -. win against Teresa Powell. The Golfers came out better on the next run as Liam Higgins had a .- win over Andy Campbell, while the rinks of Liam Sharvin and Alan Telford finished in a - draw.After tea the two games were shared with a -. win for the home Sharvin four and an away win for David Gibson of .- to secure his double.Bright won the match in the final two games as Hugh Porter doubled up with a -. win and Niall Polley finished the match off with a - win to take the overall score.The other match in the ision saw Marina travel to surprise package Loughinisland and it was the Islanders who came out on top with a .-. points win, which moved them ahead of their visitors into third position in the table..prettyPhoto

title: Security firm policing council’s new facility without electricity
story: A PRIVATE security firm has been employed to police Downpatrickrsquos new poundm household recycling centre.The Flying Horse Road facility mdash which opened in October mdash has no mains electricity to power the ultra-modern sitersquos high-tech security system, rendering it inoperable.As a result, the local authority is paying for a private security firm to police the centre outside its normal operating hours, but is refusing to say how much this is costing ratepayers whoare also footing the bill for the hire of a generator.It has been installed to supply electricity at the centre to power lights, staff accommodation and some specialised skips and containers which are capable of compacting materials, including cardboard.Council officials have confirmed that the power supplied by the generator is not adequate to run the Flying Horse Road centrersquos CCTV cameras which are dotted around the site, but hopes to have mains power installed as soon as possible.Over recent years, signicant sums have been invested in new civic amenity sites in Ballynahinch and Castlewellan, with the Flying Horse Road facility described as one of the most modern of its kind.It opened amid a blaze of publicity and coincided with confirmation that the amount of waste being recycled locally is above the Northern Ireland target with the Newry, Mourne and Down area now one of the provincersquos top recycling authorities.The district is recycling just over % of its waste and has passed the Northern Ireland average for the first time. Over the past year, the level of recycled waste has increased by %.Downpatrick councillor Dermot Curran hopes the work to provide mains power to the new Flying Horse Road facility is completed as soon as possible.ldquoI do not know why there is no mains power but it is a little embarrassing that the CCTV cameras at a poundm centre cannot be operated and we have had to hire in a private security firm, he said.ldquoThis represents an additional cost to already hard-pressed ratepayers and I hope that we are talking about days, not weeks, for the mains power to be supplied. It is an issue council officers need to be on top of.Cllr Curran said that many people were keen to see the new centre opened, given that its predecessor at nearby Cloonagh Road was struggling to cope with the huge demand being placed upon it.He continued: ldquoIt is great to have such a modern recycling facility on our doorstep to meet the needs of people who are clearly recycling their waste in increasing numbers. The new centre is being well used and the council deserves credit for this major investment but, in my opinion, the mains power issue should have been sorted before it opened for business.Cllr Curran said that given the increased emphasis on recycling, the council is behind innovative plans to allow groups and charities across the district to reuse ious items dumped at household recycling centres in Downpatrick, Castlewellan and Ballynahinch.He added: ldquoA number of groups have expressed an interest in taking part and I have no doubt that this scheme will be a success with ious items destined for the scrapheap given a new lease of le.A council spokeswoman confirmed that the recycling centre was operating without mains power.ldquoIt has taken longer than anticipated to connect the mains power supply at the new site, said the spokeswoman.ldquoAs a temporary measure, a generator and security firm are being used to cover requirements. Newry, Mourne and Down Council is working to have the mains power installed as soon as possible.The Recorder asked the local authority how much it is paying the security firm to police the new civic amenity site outside its normal operating hours but was not provided with an answer..prettyPhoto

title: Sr Bartholomew’s centenary celebrations
story: THE family of a Leitrim nun, who has lived in Africa for  years, flew thousands of miles to help her celebrate her  birthday.Sr Mary Bartholomew was joined by five nieces, including Dympna Kelly and Eileen Ramsey from her home village, who arrived in Port Elizabeth, South Africa, to mark her milestone birthday last week.Another niece, Mary McAleenan, from Slievnaboley, near Leitrim, who wasnrsquot able to make the journey, says her aunt had been on an adventure since she left home in  on board the Warwick Castle to care for ldquothe poorest of the poor amid the soaring heat of South Africa.Sr Bartholmew, was born Philomena Cunningham on December , , and enjoyed growing up with her four sisters and three brothers on what is now known as Kilnhill Road in Leitrim.She and her older sister, Mary Bernadette, who also became a nun, were among the first girls to play camogie in Leitrim before an official team had even been set up by the local Fontenoys GAA club.She was educated at Sacred Heart Grammar School in Newry and with her heart set on a religious vocation she entered the Assumption Convent in Ballynahinch just as World War II began.Her niece, Mary, said that being a nun in those days brought honour to a family and having two daughters as nuns set the Cunninghams apart within their small rural village.ldquoThere were nine other postulants accompanying Sr Bartholomew on the long voyage across to Africa. Her ship was the last passenger ship to sail to the continent for many years, as most ships were then commissioned for the war effort, Mary explained.The young nun swapped the green fields and rain of home for the blistering heat and bustle of Grahamstown in the Eastern Cape, which must have been quite an experience.She completed her religious formation and academic teacher training before taking her vows in . Over the following decades she taught in several schools. Eventually, on retiring, she was assigned a new mission, opening a clinic and a pre-school within an encampment that catered for over , refugees fleeing the horrors of the Mozambique war.In Sr Bartholomewrsquos own words of this period in her le, recorded in a book written over  years ago, Drumgooland ndash A Parish Divided, she recalls: ldquoWith missionary zeal we did our utmost over the following years to render whatever assistance we could to the many thousands of refugees, I taught including adults.ldquoThese poor people had a minimum of education and were eager to learn English. After class we would sit around and read the bible in Shangaan, the local language, and gave help when it was needed.Niece Mary takes up the story again. She added: ldquoNuns donrsquot retire and while Sr Bartholomew found the intense heat too much after several years, she made for the cooler environment of an office and spent time in general admin.Sr Bartholomew would often make the trip back home to Leitrim after Vatican II came to pass when the rigours and discipline of a pious le became more relaxed in the s. However, she was always looked forward to going back to Port Elizabeth.Her last trip home was some years ago when her older sister, Eileen, was seriously ill.ldquoShe had managed to hold her hand and chat briefly before she passed away, Mary recalled. She stayed until Eileenrsquos months mind,and left shortly after. This was the last time she was home..prettyPhoto

title: Teenager Sophie fundraising for blind charity
story: A BALLYNAHINCH teenager has embarked upon a fundraising initiative on behalf of the Guide Dogs for the Blind Association.Sophie Millswill be selling raffle tickets for a host of prizes over the coming weeks ahead of a a key fundraising event in Ballynahinch Masonic Hall on February  next year.The Year  Ballynahinch High School student mdash who has been diagnosed with Albinism mdash is on the waiting list for a guide dog and has already been cane-trained by representatives from the charity.The teenager, who relies on the aid of her cane, is hoping that she will get her guide dog sometime next year, but is conscious that there is a long waiting list.Sophie, who recently finished in the top six of a SuperValu Superstars competition and was presented with a certicate during a glittering awards night at Belfastrsquos Titanic Hotel, is keen to help the Guide Dogs charity by raising money on its behalf.Her mum Marina said the estimated cost of training a guide dog is pound,.She explained: ldquoSophie wants to raise as much money as she can to help the charity which does not receive any government funding. It is her way of giving something back to an organisation which is helping her and so many others.ldquoSophie studies at Ballynahinch High School with the help of a classroom assistant and is keen to raise as much as she can.Her mum said that a number of local businesses have been very generous in offering raffle prizes and she hopes that others will kindly donate some more.Marina added: ldquoAn evening of live music gets underway at .pm and the entry fee is pound. The winners of the raffle will be drawn on the night and Sophie hopes the evening will be a success..prettyPhoto

title: Tourism centre future talks put back to New Year
story: DISCUSSIONS on the future of Downpatrickrsquos visitor information centre are to be held early in the New Year.It was widely expected that talks about the future of the dedicated centre would have been held on Monday evening, but the matter did not feature on the agenda of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and TourismCommittee meeting.As exclusively revealed in the Recorder last month, Downpatrick could lose its dedicated visitor information centre under radical proposals being considered by the local authority.The issue was briefly debated during a behind-closed-doors meeting of the councilrsquos ERT Committee in Newry last month, with the matter again raised at last weekrsquos meeting of the full council by Downpatrick councillor Cadogan Enright.He criticised the local authority for agreeing to hold discussions on the future of the visitor facility mdash located at the St Patrick Centre mdash in secret.While no formal decision has yet been made, the Recorder understands that council officers are considering ending the dedicated presence of staff in their current base at the St Patrick Centre in the town.Council officials have confirmed that a report which considered the future opportunities for visitor information centres within the district was tabled for discussion in November, with the meeting held in committee and no final decision made.It is understood that there had been no consultation with local politicians about the future of the visitor information centres prior to last monthrsquos proposal being discussed.Last week, the council chief executive, Mrs Marie Ward, explained that as the visitor information centre issue debated by the ERT committee fell under a section of the local government act in relation to financial or business affairs, it was not for public discussion.She added: ldquoAs staff are involved I think it important to make it clear that there is no proposal to close the visitor information centre in Downpatrick. The matter will be discussed at the next ERT Committee..prettyPhoto

title: Traders’ interest in shop front scheme
story: FIFTEEN traders have expressed an interest in taking part in a pound, scheme aimed at revitalising shop fronts at Irish Street in Downpatrick.The new scheme mdash which is being spearheaded by Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Department for Communities mdash follows the completion earlier this year of a protracted public realm initiative.A number of formal planning applications paving the way for the work to start have been lodged recently.Scheduled to last three months, the pound, scheme took six months to complete due to a series of issues including the discovery of asbestos piping and problems with a sewer. Contractors also encountered problems with the foundations of the old blast wall at the former PSNI station.The Department for Infrastructure, which managed the problem-ridden public realm scheme on behalf of the Department for Communities and Newry, Mourne and Down Council, admitted that the delay had had a ldquonegative impact on trading across the town.Government officials also conceded that more should have been done to keep the Downpatrick business community affected by the overrunning regeneration project better informed.Confirmation that  traders have expressed an interest in the revitalisation scheme was confirmed at this weekrsquos meeting of the local councilrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee.A steering group has been established to oversee the scheme and will work alongside an architect and quantity surveyor to deliver the project.News of the interest in the revitalisation scheme comes ahead of a planned meeting in the New Year to discuss the redevelopment of the former Irish Street police station site and a number of adjacent empty buildings.The meeting, which will be attended by council officials and representatives from a number of statutory agencies, is designed to provide traders with an opportunity to have their say on the ambitious retail and commercial proposal aimed at transforming the townrsquos economy.During the meeting, the discussion will help guide the development brief process aimed at paving the way for work on the multi-million pound plan to start.The development brief will outline what the local authority would like to see developed in Irish Street to maximise the potential of every square inch of available space, with permission recently secured to purchase an outstanding piece of ground close to the Irish Street car park to allow the ambitious proposal to proceed.When the blueprint for the future development of the site has been agreed, it will be advertised, inviting developers to come forward to transform the site to kick-start a signicant town centre economic regeneration initiative.Marks and Spencer and Home Bargains are reported to be interested in opening new premises in Downpatrick and view Irish Street as an ideal location as there are currently no other suitable sites available.Itrsquos now over two years since it was revealed that the former police station site had been earmarked for a major economic regeneration initiative which could potentially include new housing.The ambitious proposal has been described as the most signicant retail and commercial investment plan ever proposed for the town centre, with politicians hopeful that the plan to transform the sprawling town centre site as part of a major investment plan will provide a major boost for existing businesses.Downpatrick councillor Dermot Curran has welcomed news that  traders have expressed an interest in the Irish Street revitalisation scheme and is encouraging traders from across the town to take part in discussions on the future of the former police base site.He said it is critically important that the Downpatrick business community has an insight into helping shape the development brief for the biggest ever investment in the town centre.Cllr Curran added: ldquoIt is important that the business community grasps the opportunity it is being given to help shape the future development of a prominent town centre site. Traders must make their voices heard on a project which has the potential to rejuvenate the town centrersquos economy, providing a boost for existing businesses through increased footfall.ldquoI firmly believe that the planned redevelopment of the huge former police base site can attract additional retail investment in the heart of the town..prettyPhoto

title: Trevor to get locks snipped in aid of meningitis research
story: CROSSGAR man Trevor Simpson is having his flowing locks chopped on Christmas Eve to raise funds for the Meningitis Research Foundation.The fundraising haircut will take place in the villagersquos Corner Inn at .pm with the operation performed by Mrs Leta McConnell, owner of My-T-Sharp Barbers.Trevorrsquos fundraiser is his way of giving something back to the charity which helped him through a serious illness after he contracted meningitis in December last year.He said that his fundraiser is to thank a ldquowonderful group of people who helped him when the became ill.In particular, Trevor says that he is grateful to the ldquofantastic staff at the Ulster Hospital in Dundonald and Saintfield Health Centre who played a vital role in helping save his le.The Meningitis Research Foundation plays a key role in the UK and Ireland by funding vital research, with Trevor keen to see awareness and training of health professionals improved to provide support and information on this health issue.He said said that ahead of his Christmas Eve fundraiser there has been a lot of support and is encouraging others to make their way to the Corner Inn on December .Anyone wishing to make a donation can contact Trevor on  ..prettyPhoto

title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health. The Ulster Farmersrsquo Union also used the opportunity to discuss the implications for local farmers post Brexit.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. title: superb quality entries at second annual calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast.Speaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and ten native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and chairman David Connolly said: Itrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.French judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors.ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.ABERDEEN ANGUSA strong entry of Aberdeen Angus calves were judged by William McLaren from the noted Netherton Herd based at Blackford in Perthshire.Stealing the limelight in the junior section was the -month-old heer, Home Farm Ebony Stunner bred by Fintan Keown, Belleek. She is a daughter of the three-times All Ireland champion Rosemead Karona, and was reserve heer calf champion at the breed clubrsquos calf show a few weeks ago.HEREFORDTaking the reserve junior award was David Wilson, Magheraveely, with the April  heer Lisrace Crystal by Knockmountage Master.Heer born between    and    - , David Wilson, Lisrace Prettymaid th by Ballyaville LelinerBull born after    - , John and William McMordie, Solpoll  National by Solpoll  Dynamite , David Wilson, Lisrace Lumberjack th by Knockmountage Master , Mervyn Richmond, Corraback Kadar by Mara Flook.Heer born after    - , David Wilson, Lisrace Crystal by Knockmountage Master , Mervyn Richmond, Corraback Guenevere th by Mara Flook.IRISH MOILEDThe Irish Moiled classes were judged by Trevor Chadwick from County Offaly. As a consequence, it now faces a rapid move towards an Irish Sea trade border.Having backed Brexit as something which would improve things, the DUP now finds that for which it dreamt and campaigned threatening to unravel the Union itself.Brexit itself and the DUP’s support not only for leaving the EU, but for a harder form of Brexit, was a key factor in the de facto nationalist and Green Party pacts in North Belfast and South Belfast which cost it two seats.The loss in North Belfast of Nigel Dodds, the party’s Westminster leader and one of unionism’s elder statesmen, is devastating.On Thursday night as it became clear that his seat was in jeopardy, one DUP member sent me a message saying: “We could lose anyone but him.”Few people across the DUP’s disparate and frequently warring factions would disagree with that sentiment.Not only is he a strategic asset to the DUP and a respected figure at Westminster in a way that some of his DUP colleagues are not, but his defeat speaks to a profound psychological problem for unionism.This seat, once held by the father of Ulster Unionism, Edward Carson, has never been held by a nationalist before – still less by a republican.As such, Mr Dodds’ defeat represents an old certainty which now is slipping away from unionism.Joint committee of Irish Parliament engages in nationalist groupthink over the de Souza citizenship case Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BELF | Article Teaser"And as the latest in a line of once impregnable unionist seats which have been lost by unionism, the result is evocative of a wider sense that not only control of Northern Ireland – but potentially Northern Ireland itself – is slipping away.There is no inevitability that a united Ireland is coming. Just four years ago, prior to Brexit and the collapse of Stormont, polls pointed to Northern Ireland being more constitutionally secure than at any point since its creation in .And even in this election, where unionism has suffered a grievous blow, Sinn Fein’s vote has fallen further than that of the DUP.The rise of the Alliance Party, astonishingly in this election the third largest party, is no guarantee of support for Irish unity.But it is a clear rejection of what has seemed like an archaic form of unionism whose biggest idea often seems to be to circle the wagons with an electoral pact when seats come under pressure.Yesterday the man who is seen by some DUP members as the great hope of unionism said something which appeared to misunderstand the core problem.Asked on Good Morning Ulster about the psychological damage of the result for unionism, Sir Jeffrey Donaldson referred to “the splintering of the unionist vote, for example, in places like North Down” and said that unionists wanted unity.It is a measure of how far unionism has fallen that a sentence like that can be uttered without drawing gasps.North Down is one of the safest unionist seats in Northern Ireland. Less than a decade ago, unionists won % of the votes there.If a unionist pact is required to stop it being lost, that is a pitul reflection on the state of the DUP and UUP.The logic of suggesting a pact in North Down is that there is almost no winnable seat which the UUP should contest without a pact.But while that would suit the DUP’s short-term interests – and perhaps even those of the UUPit gained a seat as a result – the evidence suggests that pacts are one of the reasons that Alliance is surging.Facing a developing fire, a move towards widespread unionist unity could act as an accelerant.Unlike nationalism, where Sinn Fein has – despite its major victory in North Belfast – had a poor election but has seen votes largely slip from it to the SDLP, this election has confirmed the complete dominance of the DUP within unionism.With that dominance comes responsibility when unionism falters.Will Arlene Foster accept that she is either accountable or responsible for any of this crisis  Or will she blame everyone but herself History suggests the latter, despite the fact that DUP members privately say that many voters expressed their unhappiness at Mrs Foster during canvassing.For a party renowned for its bare-toothed ruthlessness, the DUP has been remarkably understanding of the failures on Mrs Foster’s watch.There was an abortive putsch after she led unionism to the first loss of its Stormont majority in the history of Northern Ireland.Those who quietly muttered about challenging her then but chose not to do so must now wonderthey could have helped prevent this catastrophe for unionism.Unionism now lacks a strong leader at the point where it needs one most.Loyalists – including paramilitaries – poured into political activism their efforts at rejecting Boris Johnson’s Irish Sea border. Now that strategy has failed, where do they go Some, based on the recent meeting in Portadown from which my colleague Ben Lowry reported, will be arguing for street protests,not outright violence.Even setting aside moral considerations, past loyalist violence has been strategically disastrous and the street disorder during the flag protests actually boosted Alliance’s vote.Unionism stands weary at another crossroads. But unlike the choice between Terence O’Neill’s moderation and the full-throated unionism of Paisleyism  years ago, this time the possibility of a vote for Irish unity is more real than many then could conceive.And this time there is a sense of unionism lacking a single leader with the ability and ideological purpose to even lead unionist opinion – let alone those now deserting unionism.try title: saints church mark armistice day special lunchtime concert
story: Monday November , is Armistice Day, marking  years since the end of the First World War.A range of tributes and commemorations are set to take place across the country on the day immediately following Remembrance Sunday.Next Monday, at pm as part of its Music at Lunchtime programme of concerts, All Saints Church in Penarth will mark the occasion with a recital entitled ldquoPeace and Love.The concert will feature well-known composer and pianist Andrew Wilson-Dickson and the church will introduce talented young violinist, Lara Fang.The concert, following a period of silence, will last around an hour and will include music by Bach, Brahms, Haydn, Mozart, Paganini and Prokoviev.Violin soloist Lara Fang has a lelong passion for music and music-making.She started to learn the violin at the age of five with Ru Yi Li, the former lead violinist of the China National Symphony Orchestra, performing in many concerts as a soloist and as part of ious youth orchestras in Shanghai, Nanjing, Yangzhou and Zhuhai.In January  she received an inidual award of lsquoExcellent Musicianrsquo from the Musicianrsquos Union of Zhuhai, China and came to the UK.In , she studied violin at the Royal Welsh College of Music and Dramawith Lesley Hatfield, the leader of the BBC National Orchestra of Wales.In  she was select to perform as a first violinist with the RWCMD string soloists.Andrew Wilson-Dickson came to Wales in  to teach at the RWCMD, where he became involved in historical performance.During this time he founded the Welsh Baroque Orchestra and the Welsh Camerata to provide resources in Wales for the performance of a wide repertoire of early music, from Machaut to Bachrsquos St John Passion.His chief delight is piano, as soloist and accompanist.In his youth he was a pupil of Lamar Crowson and John Lill and he has given countless performances and many broadcasts - particularly of music for piano duet and two pianos. saw the first performance of his full-scale oratorio Karuna, provoked by a world sliding into confrontation.Two years later he composed a completed version of JS Bachs St Mark Passion.Mr Wilson-Dicksons book The Story of Christian Musicis a product of his involvement for many years in church music.It has sold worldwide in more than a dozen languages across Europe and the Far East.Entry to the All Saints Church ldquoMusic at Lunchtime programme of concerts is free with donations gratefully accepted and shared between ldquoAll Saints Music and a charity of the performers choice ndash Miss Fang has chosen Cancer Research Wales.The church opens its doors at .pm for refreshments and audience members are invited to bring their lunch.For more information, phone organiser Dafydd G. title: charity christmas cards designed tabernacle foodbank unveiled
story: Mark Hole, left, Frank Collict, and Reggie the dog" Charity Christmas cards designed by Penarth locals for foodbank unveiledThe card with Penarth in the snow" Charity Christmas cards designed by Penarth locals for foodbank unveiledThe card painted by Frnak Collict" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentHALLOWErsquoEN may have just come and gone but many in Penarth are already casting their eyes towards Christmas.Mark Hole of Penarth is one such man, having produced his own set of Christmas cards of Penarth in the snow for charity - but he is looking for sponsors to help with the costs."Last year, it was just a photo of Penarth in the snow," he said. "It was actually St Davids Day, but I thought it looked quite Christmassy!"Ive levelled it up this year, after we sold - with just that picture. This year, we got Frank Collict, a local artist in to do another card - this time a painting of Penarth Pier in the snow.All the profits from the cards go to the Tabernacle Church foodbank. After last years run was paid for out of pocket by Mr Hole, he sought a sponsor, and found one in the form of Welsh energy supplier Our Footprints, who have covered the costs of printing and advertising in full."Theyve been fantastic - thanks to them,  per cent of the profits are going to the food bank," said Mr Hole."I moved back to Penarth three years ago after suffering a breakdown in Brighton. The foodbank there was essential in getting me back on my feet."Every Thursday they do drop ins for people to pick up parcels, and do social breakfast mornings. Its a brilliant place run by volunteers and Im just happy to do something to give back to them."Theres also a memorial on the back to a friend of mine who passed away this year, as a mark of respect to him and his husband."Cards can be brought from Snells, Four Ways Newsagents and Gts and Number Nine from the beginning of November for pound. title: k pay gap vale glamorgans top bottom earners
story: The Equality Trust says figures from the Office for National Statistics, which reveal a gap of nearly pound, between the UKs highest and lowest earners, "paint a depressing picture of dangerous income inequality".In the Vale of Glamorgan, the average weekly pay packet for the top  per cent of earners in full-time roles is now . times those in the bottom fth ndash a gap of pound,.More News:Charity Christmas cards designed for Tabernacle foodbank unveiledNew poundm Five Mile Lane upgrade floods just weeks after openingPenarths RNLI crew on the hunt for new membersThe figures, for workers who live in the area, use median, rather than mean, averages, to stop them being skewed by particularly small or large salaries.They show the top  per cent of earners were paid pound weekly on average, or pound, annually.For low earners, weekly pay was just pound ndash pound, a year.The average full-time employee in the Vale of Glamorgan works . hours per week, with a median annual salary of pound,.The figures refer to basic pay and do not include bonuses or overtime.The pay gap between the Vale of Glamorgans highest and lowest earners is slightly larger than the UK average.Across the UK, the average annual salary for the top % of earners is . times as high than the lowest earners.Top earners are paid pound, on average, compared to pound, for their lowest-paid counterparts.London had the greatest gap, where top-paid earners took home pound, ndash nearly pound, more than low earners.Most equal was Wales, where the highest  per cent of earners were paid . times that of the lowest fth.Dr Wanda Wyporska, executive director of charity the Equality Trust, said: "Just like the gender pay gap, the gap between high and low paid workers is not shrinking fast enough."But this is an even greater scandal because the evidence shows that in countries with high levels of inequality, like the UK, there are higher levels of violent crime, physical and mental ill-health, infant mortality and lower levels of trust and educational attainment."By continuing to ignore inequality, decision makers are failing to truly realise the social and economic potential of this country."The Trades Union Congress estimates one in nine UK workers are in insecure and poorly paid "precarious work", including those on zero-hours contracts and self-employed people making less than the minimum wage.General secretary Frances OGrady said: "Working people deserve a fairer share of the wealth they create. Its not right that millions are struggling to make ends meet, while those at the top pocket bumper pay cheques."We need to reset the balance of power in our economy."That means giving workers new rights so they can access the protection of a union in every workplace and bargain for better pay and conditions across industries." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: bears head flushes away competition
story: The Bears Head in Windsor Road has been awarded a platinum rating by inspectors in the Loo of the Year Awards .The awards are aimed at highlighting and improving standards of away from home toilet provision across the UK.Loo of the Year Awards inspectors make unannounced visits to thousands of toilets at sites across the UK, in order to judge them.All of the toilets are graded silver, gold, platinum or diamond with unacceptable toilets not graded at all.The toilets are judged against numerous criteria, including deacutecor and maintenance, cleanliness, accessibility, hand washing and drying equipment and overall management.The Bears Head, a Wetherspoon pub, is managed by Nick Newport.Mr Newport said: "We are delighted with the award."Staff at the pub ensure the toilets are in first-class condition at all times and it is great that this has been recognised by the inspectors."The Loo of the Year Awards managing director, Mike Bone, said: "The toilets at The Bears Head have been designed and fitted out to a very high standard and are both clean and well maintained."The pub richly deserves its platinum award." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. on Sunday, November  as the closest Sunday to November .As in previous years, the parade was a joint effort between the Penarths Royal British Legionbranch and a committee of members of the Penarth Ex Services Club, a group of serving and veteran military personnel from all arms of Her Majestys Armed Forces.A parade formed up in Station Approach at am and marched off at .am to the Garden of Remembrance, at the corner of Alexandra Gardens on Rectory Road.There a wreath laying ceremony took place, and two minutes silence was observed.The procession then proceeded up Windsor Terrace and down.The following day, at .am on November , the Royal British Legion held a short ceremony at the junction of Windsor Road and Glebe Street.The Legion then proceeded to St Augustinersquos Church to Penarth Veterans Committee and some families attended the Cenotaph in Alexandra Park to pay respects in advance of Remembrance Day.The chairmen of the veterans committee, Simon Shirley, and of the title: inspector calls andy rice
story: Irsquom pleased to say that the recent festivities for Hallowersquoen and Guy Fawkes Night passed without any major concerns or crime.We policed the Penarth fireworks event on the th November which was very well attended by local communities.I can report there were no Hallowersquoen anti-social behaviour incidents or crimes that we had to deal with.Additional officers were out and about during Hallowersquoen and targeted known anti-social behaviour hotspots.I would like to thank any parents that took the time to educate their children about safe, sensible and respectful trick or treating.I would also like to thank the schools and shops that participated in our Operation Bang crime prevention programme.On a final note, I would like to remind residents about bogus tradesmen, door-to-door sales or doorstep fraud which involves fraudsters knocking at your door and trying to steal money from you by using a scam.ldquoFraudsters attempt to pressurise you into buying something you actually donrsquot want or something thatrsquos very poor value for money.I would advise people not to allow cold callers access to their property.Also, look out for elderly relatives and neighbours and contact the police immediatelyyou are approached by anyone suspicious.In addition to this, Action Fraud have released advice recently informing the public that your bank or the police will never send someone to your home to collect cash, bank cards or your PIN.There have been reports of this happening on a national basis, which has been named as lsquocourier fraudrsquo.Action Fraud are also warning the public about another scam where people are phoned and told theyrsquove been charged for an Amazon Prime subscription.I would advise you to never install software as a result of a cold call and always refuse unusual requests for personal or financial information.With Christmas around the corner, I would ask that the public remain vigilant with their finances and property.If story: The exterior of Headland#s School, Penarth. Picture: Google" School of the Month: Headlands SchoolPrincipal Matthew Burns" School of the Month: Headlands SchoolThe #Cafe # is staffed by pupils" School of the Month: Headlands SchoolStudents can interview each other and produce radio for #The Voice#" School of the Month: Headlands SchoolStudents hard at work on The Voice" School of the Month: Headlands SchoolEstyn rated the school #excellent# in wellbeing and attitudes to learninltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtg care support and ltspan classtruncate-full-screengtguidance and leadership lt spangtlt spangtlt spangt" School of the Month: Headlands SchoolThe school drama team has been invited to perform for the Senedd" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA SCHOOL is a community is a common saying, but nowhere is that more apparent than Headlands.Headlands School is an independent special school, offering day and residential placements for pupils aged  to .The schools caters to pupils who have dficulty learning as a result of early trauma, complex emotional and social issues, Autism Spectrum Conditionsand Aspergerrsquos Syndrome.As the Penarth Times previously reported, Estyn, office of Her Majestyrsquos Inspectorate for Education and Training in Wales, recognised Headlands School for their excellence in wellbeing and attitudes to learning care support and guidance and leadership and management.The glowing report was thoroughly well-deserved.Sian Wood, the schoolrsquos business support officer, took me on a tour of the school site. It boasts a unique approach to teaching vocational skills, as well as academic and sports facilities.In particular, one alleyway on the school site had seen sheds transformed into small businesses, which the pupils ran - earning qualications and gathering valuable work experience, with staff and students hoping to open it up to the public soon.ldquoItrsquos a bit like Diagon Alley, isnrsquot it  said Ms Wood. Here the school hosts its own bike repair shop, in the form of Spokes, a cafe, its own radio station - The Voice - and plans for a zero-waste food shop are well under way.Robin Hackett, head of KS, showed me around some of the buildings.ldquoThe cafe opened to our students around July time, and was fully operational and officially in September, for the new academic year, he said.ldquoIt opened at the same time as our radio station, with money generously donated from the Postcode Community Trust.ldquoNext on the agenda is our plan to open a fully zero-waste food shop. Wersquove been having talks with other similar shops around Cardf and here in Penarth, like Foxyrsquos, about how to do it.ldquoThe idea is that, because wersquore a residential school, it will give our pupils a place to shop for things like cereal, fruit, biscuits and so on without plastic wrappers or other waste.ldquoOur initial, short-term plan is to reduce our own, internal impact on the environment, butwe can get it up and running to the extent we want, we may as well open it to the local community. Imagine - popping over to the school, grab a tea or a coffee, do your food shop and get your bike serviced, all by our pupils.The pupils I spoke to were enthusiastic about opening their school to the community, and plenty of them had applied for shts in the shop and cafe.One proudly told me he had secured shts in the cafe, and while we peered through the window into the future site of the zero-waste shop, he made sure I noticed the poster for the Lego club. He was the president of it.ldquoWersquore hoping to open the shop in January, said Mr Hackett. ldquoWersquore just waiting on the builders now.ldquoA lot of kids here struggle in academic settings, so this is all building good skills for the future. Our philosophy is, one percent change at a time adds up to a lot.We moved across the alleyway to the schoolrsquos music room.It was well-stocked with plenty of high-tech equipment, from first-class ampliers to cutting-edge keyboards. Excitingly, the school also has a state-of-the-art soundbooth on the way from Germany.ldquoWersquore looking to rent it out to local bands and others as a rehearsal and recording space, once wersquove built it up to the second floor, said Mr Hackett. ldquoWersquore investing in better equipment, and wersquoll be holding radio production workshops with the local primaries, like Victoria Road.The school doesnrsquot just offer vocational opportunities, either.ldquoRecently a lot of pupils went to Belgium, to Ypres, said principal Matthew Burns. ldquoThe best part is they cycled most of the way there!ldquoOver five days, they would cycle a huge distance, and then ride a coach or the Eurostar partway. That way, they got all the way to Ypres, to hear the Last Post and lay a wreath.ldquoWe also put a lot of emphasis on sport, with a state of the art Astroturf we rent out to the community, and a great football team - we recently attended a tournament at Heronsbridge and only narrowly lost to the overall winners.ldquoOutside of that, our KS group are putting together a foodbox raiser for Christmas for those in need, and wersquove just had our drama and music department invited to put on a production for the Senedd.With IT suites, science labs and gymnasiums, this barely scratched the surface of what the school had to offer. Itrsquos no surprise the school has been so successful, with such close attention from its staff. As a school focussing on children with learning dficulties, the pupil number is kept low, with around  pupils attending at any one time. The largest class has eight pupils, with most having fewer.ldquoWe have around  day pupils and  at the moment in residential, staying in one of our four homes on and off the site, said Ms Wood. ldquoFor those children, we offer a  week-a-year provision.ldquoThe houses are lovely - we really want it to feel like their own home, their own bedroom, with their belongings.ldquoIt forms part of our relational approach - how we talk to our children and how we talk to each other. If we have a new pupil arrive here, the first thing to focus on is building a positive relationship with them.ldquoThe conversations are all about recognising whatrsquos going on and supporting them, in their own time.Judging by the smiles on the faces of staff and students alike, itrsquos an approach to be emulated the world over. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: view senedd vaughan gething
story: It is an issue that features heavily in my assembly postbag.I have been contacted by a number of local residents who are concerned about the availability of GP or other health care professionals for an appointment.The recent National Survey results showed continued concern over access with  per cent of participants finding it dficult to make an appointment at their practice.However  per cent of us were happy with our last episode of local healthcare.The NHS is facing unprecedented challenges with rising demand, expectation and long term public health challenges.We face those challenges against a backdrop of austerity imposed by the UK Government.I have previously spoken about our investment in community pharmacy, mental health counselling and physiotherapy services as key parts of local healthcare.We are though all aware of the pressures on our hardworking GPs and their practice teams to meet demand.I am incredibly proud of all our NHS staff who do a fantastic job despite the challenges they face.There is no single solution to improving access and a number of initiatives are underway including poundm invested in this yearrsquos contract with GPs.I am confident that we will help to relieve pressure on our GPs whilst also meeting the publicrsquos expectation.Last week, I was delighted to announce that the Train Work Live scheme has once again helped to exceed our targets for GP training.I launched the scheme in  to promote Wales as an excellent place for doctors and their families to train, work and live.We know that there are very real challenges across about recruiting and retaining GPs. This is not unique to Wales but an issue across the UK.Itrsquos important we act to ensure that our health service is sustainable in the long term.Recent figures show excellent progress has been made again this year.I increased the number of GP training places from  to  this year.However we actually filled  places.This is an increase of  per cent on last year and is great news for us locally.In order to ensure that we can recruit the medical workforce our health service needs now and in the future we also need to look outside Wales. That is why I recently visited India.The British Association of Physicians of Indian Origin have led the Medical Training Initiativescheme to bring medical professionals from India to work in NHS Wales for up to two years.This partnership with NHS Wales has led to over  doctors a year for the last three years being offered positions in NHS Wales through the scheme.During my visit I had the pleasure of meeting with some of the candidates who have applied to train work and live in Wales for two years together with the NHS Wales recruitment team.Our message that Wales is an excellent place to Train, Work and Live is clearly having an effect at home and abroad.As ever, I would be interested on hearing your views on this, please do get in touch. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. are a  per cent increase on the same period last year.The Vale Foodbank is part of the Trussell Trustrsquos network, which announced that the need for emergency food parcels in the UK is at an all-time high.The new figures come after the Trussell Trust released State of Hunger, the most in-depth study ever published into hunger and the drivers of food bank use in the UK.The findings revealed the average weekly income of people at food banks is only pound after paying housing costs, and almost one in five have no money coming in at all in the month before being referred for emergency food.The Vale Foodbank is backing the Trussell Trustrsquos call for candidates on all sides to work towards a future where no one needs a food bank and pledge to protect people from hunger by ensuring everyone has enough money for the basics.The Trussell Trust is asking our next government to end the five week wait for universal credit ensure benefit payments cover the cost of living and invest in local emergency support for people in crisis.The local increase in need for the food bank is due to people struggling with the five-week wait for a first universal credit payment and people receiving payments that donrsquot cover the cost of essentials.Vale Foodbank trustee, Susan Lloyd-Selby said: ldquoItrsquos a real concern that in just six months wersquove provide , emergency supplies to local people.ldquoThese figures donrsquot take into account our busiest time of year - as the colder weather draws in, we often find even more people needing our help.ldquoWe believe that everyone should have enough money coming in to cover the basics. But right now, more and more people in the Vale are being forced to our food bankrsquos doors.ldquoThis isnrsquot right.ldquoWhile our help is needed, wersquore dedicated to ensuring that people in our community without enough money for food are able to access emergency support.ldquoOur vital work in the community has only been possible because of the incredible generosity shown by local people who have donated food, time and funds.ldquoThank you.The Vale Foodbank is particularly in need of UHT milk, fruit juice, tinned meat, and tinned vegetables.The charity has asked for festive donations to be donated in early December at the latest, to ensure volunteers have enough time to process and distribute these donations to people before Christmas. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: welsh trekkers raise   marie curie hospice
story: The team included Marie Curie nurses, volunteers, and family members of those cared for by the charity, with the proceeds going to people in need across the country - including Penarthrsquos own Marie Curie hospice.They tackled demanding daily hikes of up to eight hours and took on the valleys and paddy fields of northern Vietnam.Lisa Richards, a Marie Curie nurse from Rhuddlan, was part of the group and has raised more than pound, for the charityrsquos services across Wales.Ms Richards has been working for the charity for almost  years and lost six stone in preparation for the challenge.She said: ldquoI am always amazed by the fantastic fundraisers who work tirelessly giving their time and energy to raise money for the charity, so thatrsquos why this year I wanted to be a part of that process.ldquoI was supported every step of the way on the trek by a fantastic group of people who lted me up when I stumbled and made me feel like Irsquod known them forever and Irsquove really made friends for le.Mariclare Carey-Jones, a BBC journalist and broadcaster and ambassador for the charityrsquos Cardf and the Vale hospice, took part in the challenge.ldquoAs an ambassador for the Vale hospice I know how important fundraising is in order to ensure the organisation can continue providing vital care and support for people with terminal illnesses and their families, she said.ldquoKnowing I could give something back to this fantastic charity that has done so much for me and my family was my main motivation for signing up to the Vietnam trek, while the opportunity to experience a new country and undertake an amazing challenge was a real added bonus.Now the charity is calling on people to sign up for its next trek to Patagonia, which will see funds raised for the Marie Curie Nursing Service across Wales - including care in the home and the hospice.Last year, Marie Curie nurses cared for more than , patients and their families across Wales, at a cost of more than poundm a year.Hannah Leckie, community fundraiser for Cardf and the Vale, said: ldquoOur treks are always very popular, whether itrsquos with people looking to take on a new challenge in a beautul country with stunning landscapes, or those whose family has been cared for at the hospice and want to give something back.ldquoWe think Patagonia could be the best adventure yet.ldquoIt will be offering all those taking part the trip of a letime while raising money for such an important local cause.To find out more about the Patagonia trek and to register your place, visit: https:tinyurl qpxnlf article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: gin  celebrate first birthday launch penarth gin
story: Gin , of Victoria Road, plans to celebrate their its birthday with a party on November .Over the course of the year, the enterprising owners ndash Ashley Boucher and Jacques Aviles ndash have seen the bar go from strength to strength, getting involved in the manufacturing process and even being filmed by BBC Wales.Penarth Gin was described by manager Gareth Llywellyn as a premium, triple distilled Welsh dry gin, naturally prominent with notes of juniper, liquorice, cardamom citrus, orris root and paradise.Mr Boucher said: ldquoFrom humble beginnings we have had a successful year and we can only thank our customers and staff for ensuring such a prosperous start, turning our dreams into reality.ldquoAs soon as we opened we knew we would be interested in venturing into the spirit manufacturing market and have since produced our very own Penarth Gin.Mr Aviles said: ldquoWe were selected by the BBC to take part in a new docuseries highlighting successful Welsh businesses run by young entrepreneurs. It looks at the journey each business has been through to get to where they are now and what plans they have for the future.ldquoGin  was chosen for its unique style and that we set it up together, two cousins under the age of .ldquoFilming took place over four sessions in the last six months, with the final planned shoot for the first year anniversary party. story: Ms Church now has permission to to open the school in her home in Dinas Powys.The Vale councils planning committee agreed to approve a planning application for the school this week.Part of the singers Awen Project, Ms Church has spoken of her hopes the project will soon start up more independent schools.As the Penarth Times previously reported, the former child star, musician, presenter and campaigner says she will pay for the school herself in its first year.It will be non fee-paying and will educate  children aged between nine and .Ms Church has said that the school would be aimed at children struggling in mainstream education, and offer pupils more of a say in their curriculum.Vale councillors were told the singer had begun teaching in her home two months ago, and that the application was therefore retrospective.The councillors were further told that the school would only be held in the Ms Churchs home for one year and the singer has agreed to the condition to find a new home for it by July  - with five options already shortlisted.The Vale councils highways department did not have any objections to the school and councillors approved the application. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
